Training Base of State Key Laboratory of Coal Science and Technology Jointly Constructed by Shanxi Province and Ministry of Science and Technology Taiyuan University of Technology Taiyuan 030024 PR China Graphical abstract Pyridine hydrogenation involving three terrace Pt atoms or two step Pt atoms differentiates the reaction pathways on two active sites, thereby resulting in disparate intermediates for hydrogenolysis on Pt catalysts. Black data denote the largest energy barrier (eV) for successive hydrogenation to the crucial intermediate, pentahydropyridine, while the red data for the single step on two active sites. The hydrodenitrogenation of nitrogen-containing heterocycles over noble metals has fundamental importance for energy and environmental science. To develop more efficient catalyst, mechanistic investigation has been conducted with a method combining in situ Fourier transformation infrared experiments and density functional theory calculations in this work. The in situ experiments indicate flatly adsorbed pyridine molecules convert to pyridinium and α-pyridyl species at higher temperature on metallic Pt of Pt/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. Pyridine hydrogenation distinctly takes place at 150 °C with the appearance of methylene stretching vibrations, and a stepwise mechanism is identified as the temperature further increases. The adsorption, hydrogenation and hydrogenolysis of pyridine on Pt are studied in detail by theoretical calculations. In line with these findings, the geometry optimization confirms pyridine preferentially adsorbs on Pt(111) and Pt(211) both in a parallel configuration. Based on the Langmuir–Hinshelwood mechanism, the results show successive hydrogenation markedly lowers the energy barrier for subsequent hydrogenolysis. The CN bond cleavage occurs via nucleophilic attack of pentahydropyridine, rather than piperidine, which determines the reaction products, including piperidine, n-pentylamine and n-pentane. The comparative study reveals both hydrogenation and hydrogenolysis are kinetically and thermodynamically more competitive on Pt(211) than Pt(111). Especially for hydrogenolysis, the coordinatively unsaturated Pt step atoms play an essential role in CN bond cleavage. Thus, hydrogenolysis is more geometric‒dependent than hydrogenation. This provides instructive information for the design of catalysts with adjustable product selectivity. Hydrodenitrogenation (HDN) is an indispensable hydrotreating process for clean fuel production. Among the most refractory nitrogen containing compounds, the six‒membered nitrogen heterocycles (e.g. pyridine and quinoline) have been extensively studied [1,2]. Even though some fundamental conclusions have been drawn, the widely accepted HDN mechanisms were proposed on the transitional metal sulfides. The multistep process of hydrogenation and hydrogenolysis usually involve coordinatively unsaturated metal sites (or sulfur vacancies) and ‒SH group (or Brønsted acid sites), respectively [3,4]. Due to the priority of hydrogenation over hydrogenolysis, metal‒catalyzed HDN continues to raise attention [5,6], but the mechanistic information is limited. To develop better HDN catalysts, it is imperative to understand the nature of active sites involved in HDN and the reaction mechanisms on metal catalysts. Given that the hydrogenation of heterocyclic ring is a prerequisite to cleave CN bond, pyridine is an ideal model compound. As a first step to initiate HDN reaction, the adsorption of pyridine is crucial. Four modes, i.e. side‒on (parallel to the surface via π‒bonding), end‒on (perpendicular to the surface via N atom), edge‒on (perpendicular to the surface via N and adjacent C atoms) and tilted (tilted to the surface via N atom) have been summarized for pyridine adsorption on the transitional metals [7]. In comparison to the sulfide and carbide catalysts, metallic Pt catalysts are claimed to be more active for pyridine HDN [5]. To different extents, the activity and selectivity of Pt catalysts depend on the particle size and structure effect, which have been well described by the cuboctahedral Pt nanoparticle model [8,9]. The supported single-atom Pt catalysts are proposed to surpass Pt nanoparticle catalysts in selective hydrogenation [10,11]. Nevertheless, pyridine HDN may be more effective on Pt nanoparticle catalysts since the adsorption and subsequent hydrogenation of aromatic ring usually involve multiple Pt atoms. For Pt nanoparticles, the surface enclosed by close‒packed (111) and stepped (211) facets resemble the flat terraces and step edges, respectively. While most studies focus on the terrace sites of flat Pt(111) or Pt(100) facets [12,13], the counterpart on the step sites remains unexplored. To deliberate the reaction mechanism, in situ Fourier transformation infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy has been exploited to analyze the bonding and configuration of reactants, intermediates and final products adsorbed on the active sites [14–16]. Oyama’s group have carried out a series of in situ FTIR experiments to investigate the hydrogenation mechanisms of heteroatom compounds, including HDN [17], hydrodesulfurization (HDS) [16] and hydrodeoxygenation [18,19], over the supported Ni2P catalysts. They found all these reactants preferred to adsorb on Ni2P surface with the heteroatom (N, S or O) singly bonding to the coordinatively unsaturated Ni sites. Furthermore, the hydrogenolysis of fully hydrogenated intermediates was supposed to be a kinetically critical step. To date, pyridine has been commonly employed to identify the type and amount of acid sites in the FTIR measurements, but studies on the hydrogenation of pyridine over metal surfaces are rare. Based on now available reports [20,21], pyridine may form pyridinium or α-pyridyl species over Pt catalysts, but no consensus has yet been reached. In fact, the adsorption geometry of pyridine on Pt surface is not immutable, but may vary with the coverage, temperature or gas atmosphere, etc. Currently, the combination of density functional theory (DFT) calculations with FTIR shows satisfactory coupling of the theoretical and experimental results on a molecular level. To interpret the experimental phenomena, numerous studies adopt DFT calculations to explore the potential active sites [22] and the mechanistic details [23]. Some works [12,24] have been done with DFT to study the adsorption geometry of pyridine, but few involve the HDN reaction. The optimized configuration of pyridine is found to be sensitive to the type of catalyst. For instance, pyridine tends to most stably adsorb on MoS2 catalyst with its molecular plane perpendicular to the surface in a η1(N) configuration [25,26]. While on the MoP catalyst, pyridine prefers to lie parallel with a most stable configuration of η4(N,C2,C3,C5) on MoP(010) [27] and η5(N,C2,C3,C5,C6) on MoP(001) [28]. Notably, different adsorption configurations often results in different reaction pathways, which may in turn explain the outstanding HDN activity of Pt‒based catalysts. Herein, we have conducted a comprehensive study on the reaction mechanism of pyridine HDN over Pt/γ-Al2O3 catalysts with a combined in situ FTIR and DFT method. To determine the active sites, the FTIR experiments were separately conducted on γ-Al2O3 and Pt/γ-Al2O3. DFT was adopted to further elucidate the hydrogenation and hydrogenolysis process of pyridine HDN on different sites (flat and step sites) of Pt surface. To our knowledge, studies on the adsorption and reaction of pyridine on the step sites of Pt(211) facet are not yet available. The main purpose of this work is to elaborate the adsorption and HDN behavior of pyridine over Pt catalyst, thereby paving the way for design of better HDN catalysts. 2 Experimental and computational method 2.1 Catalyst preparation and characterization The γ-Al2O3 support was prepared by calcination of pseudoboehmite powder (Shandong Aluminum Co. Ltd., China) at 550 °C for 4 h. Pt/γ-Al2O3 catalyst precursor was prepared by ultrasonic assisted incipient wetness impregnation of γ-Al2O3 with an H2PtCl6∙6H2O (Aladdin, ACS, China) solution, oven drying and then calcination at 500 ºC for 4h. The nominal loading of Pt is 0.5 wt%. The surface area was calculated with nitrogen adsorption isotherm, which was obtained at ‒196 ºC on a Quantachrome Autosorb‒iQ instrument. CO FTIR measurements were conducted on liquid–nitrogen–cooled FTIR spectrometer Bruker Tensor 27 equipped with a stainless cell. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurement was carried out under high vacuum on a Kratos Analytical AXIS Supra spectrometer. The binding energy was calibrated with C 1s of 284.8 eV. The dispersion and particle size of Pt were measured by CO pulse chemisorption with 5% (v/v) CO/Ar at 40 ºC on a Micrometrics ASAP 2020 analyzer. The calculation of Pt dispersion and Pt particle size, the process of CO FTIR measurements and steady-state reactions are presented in the supplementary materials in detail. 2.2 In situ FTIR experimentation In situ FTIR measurements of pyridine HDN were also conducted on Bruker Tensor 27 connecting to an in situ quartz reaction cell. Spectra within 4000–600 cm−1 were attained under different conditions, and the resolution for scanning was 4 cm−1. Prior to the experiment, the pressed flake (ca. 10 mg with 12.6 mm diameter) was preheated at 300 °C for 1 h under He flow (60 Nml/min), then the inlet gas was switched to H2 (60 Nml/min) to reduce the catalyst for another 1 h. Background spectra were recorded once the samples naturally cooled to 20 °C, and all spectra were treated with background subtraction. Pyridine was bubbled into the cell with He flow (160 Nml/min) until saturation at room temperature and atmospheric pressure. The excess pyridine was removed by He flush for 1 h, and all spectra were gradually recorded at 20, 100, 150, 200, 250 and 300 °C. The pyridine vapor pressure (2.85 kPa at 293 K) determined by the Antoine equation has also been described elsewhere [29]. The spectra were collected after stabilizing for 3 min at the respective temperatures. To exclude the overlap of the adsorption bands by the support, the experiments were both conducted on γ-Al2O3 and Pt/γ-Al2O3. 2.3 DFT calculations DMol3 program package as part of Materials Studio was well adopted for the DFT calculations. The exchange correlation energies were considered and dealt with the generalized gradient approximation [30,31]. The DFT semi–core pseudopotential was accounted for the Pt atoms while an all–electron basis set was flexibly chosen to treat C, H and N atoms [32]. The double numerical plus polarization functions were employed to expand the valence electron functions [33]. Spin polarization was considered in all computations. The optimized lattice constant of bulk Pt (4.01 Å) is well consistent with the reported values [32,34]. A three‒layer slab was modeled with the bottom layer fixed while the topmost two layers with relevant adsorbates were relaxed. A p(4 × 4) and a p(2 × 3) supercells were built for Pt(111) and Pt(211) to simulate the reactivity of pyridine on the flat and step sites of Pt surface, respectively. As shown in Table S1 of supporting information, these two supercells are large enough for pyridine adsorption since the configuration and adsorption energy barely change when the coverage lowers to approximately equal values of 1/16 and 1/18 monolayer, respectively. The vacuum region was set to 14 Å to avoid interactions between neighboring slabs. 3 × 3 × 1 k‒point was adopted for all adsorption calculations. The convergence tolerance of self–consistent field was 1 × 10−5 Ha. To accelerate convergence, the smearing was specified to 0.005 Ha, while the cutoff radius was 4.0 Å. Energies presented here were all extrapolated to 0 K. Similar slab models and approaches have been adopted to draw valid conclusions in previous studies [35,36]. The adsorption energy ( E ads ) was determined by E ads = E Pt+Py - ( E Pt + E Py ) , where E Pt+Py denotes the energy of each pyridine and derivatives adsorbed on two different Pt slabs, E Pt the energy of bare Pt slab without adsorption of any species, and E Py the energy of each free pyridine and derivatives. Transition state was identified by complete LST/QST method [32], the convergence was achieved by setting the root–mean–square of atomic force to 0.01 Ha/Å. Two equations were used to obtain the reaction energy ( E rxn ) and energy barrier ( E a ): E rxn = E P - E R and E a = E T - E R , where E R , E T and E P refer to the total energy of reactant (R), transition state (T) and product (P) on Pt slabs, respectively. A positive value of E rxn indicates an endothermic reaction; otherwise, it is exothermic. 3 Results 3.1 In situ FTIR spectra analysis The basic characteristics of the samples are summarized in Table 1 , which have been previously reported [37]. CO FTIR measurements have been carried out to identify the active sites on Pt surfaces. Fig. 1 a depicts that three bands appear at 2077, 2053 and 2032 cm−1 with different intensities at 20 °C, which can be assigned to the stretch vibration of linearly adsorbed CO on well-coordinated terrace sites and under-coordinated step sites of metallic Pt° nanoparticles, respectively. The definitely higher intensity of the band at 2053 cm−1 than 2077 cm−1 indicates that the adsorption of CO at the step sites is stronger than the terrace sites. This is consistent with the IR experiment and calculation results [38,39]. Prolonging the flushing time to 1 h makes no difference to the adsorption behavior. However, these bands shift to higher wavenumber as the temperature rises. Fig. 1b shows the intensity of 2053 cm−1 increases at below 200 °C but gradually decreases as the desorption temperature rises to 300 °C, while the band at 2077 cm−1 relating to CO linearly adsorbed on the terrace sites vanishes at 200 °C. XPS characterization in Fig. 1c shows the binding energy of Pt on the surface of reduced catalyst is 313.8 eV, which further confirms that Pt mainly exists in the form of Pt° on Al2O3 [40]. The results of steady-state experiments in Fig. 1d indicate that pyridine conversion increases from 3.4 %–40.6 % as the reaction temperature increases to 300 °C. Pyridine was almost completely hydrogenated to piperidine when the temperature was not more than 200 °C. As the temperature increased to 250 °C, besides piperidine (91.2 %), the denitrogenated product n-pentane formed with a selectivity of 8.1 %. The product composition becomes complicated at 300 °C, besides the piperidine (71.1 %) and n-pentane (20.4 %), n-pentylpiperidine (8.4 %) was also detected. n-pentylpiperidine is assumed to be a side product which may yield from the disproportionation of two piperidine molecules or the condensation of piperidine and n-pentylamine [41]. The strong acidity of the support, determining from the reserved absorbance bands of pyridine at 300 °C in Fig. 2 , probably contributed to the formation of n-pentylpiperidine [42]. The highly reactive hydrogenated intermediates (e.g. n-pentylamine) cannot be detected in the gas chromatography analysis. To get a deep insight into the reaction mechanism of pyridine HDN over the practical Pt/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, the in situ FTIR experiments have been conducted. The FTIR analysis was first conducted on the bare γ-Al2O3 to clarify the role of support. Fig. 2 depicts the spectra of γ-Al2O3 after pyridine adsorption at different temperatures under He flow (case I). Three bands at 3733, 3681 and 3565 cm−1 assigned to surface −OH groups disappear due to the hydrogen‒bonded interaction with pyridine. These bands reappear after desorbing pyridine at above 100 °C (Fig. S1). This is confirmed by the attenuated bands at 3085, 3068, 3035 cm−1 for aromatic CH stretching of pyridine. In Fig. 2b, 1612, 1575, 1483 and 1442 cm−1 belong to the stretching and deformation vibrations of pyridine ring adsorbed on the Lewis acid sites (LAS) in the 8a, 8b, 19a, 19b modes, respectively. Pervasive blue shifts occur at 200 °C as the coverage decreases, which result from the intermolecular rearrangement and configuration transformation of pyridine molecules. At high coverage, pyridine weakly adsorbs on γ-Al2O3 via N atom. As the coverage decreases, pyridine reorients to a stable side–on mode due to the impaired intermolecular interactions. In Fig. 2c, 1218, 1147 and 1068 cm−1 arise from ring stretching and in‒plane CH bending of pyridine [43]. Another band at 1031 cm−1 appears for the asymmetric ring breathing of pyridine [7], but it readily vanishes at temperatures above 100 °C. To examine the hydrogenation behavior of pyridine over γ-Al2O3, the carrier gas was subsequently switched to H2 (case II). The FTIR spectra (not shown here) are invariant compared with those obtained under He flow, even at high temperatures. This result manifests that the LAS alone cannot catalyze the hydrogenation of pyridine, which agrees well with the point made by Duan et al. [5] that the Al2O3 support was inactive for pyridine HDN. The insufficient catalytic activity of γ-Al2O3 probably attributes to its low ability to supply active H species. Thus, the presence of metal or metal‒like sites to activate H2 seems essential. Fig. 3 a‒c depicts the FTIR spectra of Pt/γ-Al2O3 with pyridine adsorption under He flow (case III). The spectra resemble those on γ-Al2O3 when the temperature is below 150 °C. Thus, it is difficult to extract the absorption bands on Pt from the overlapped spectra on γ-Al2O3. However, once the temperature increases to 200 °C, some bands become distinguishable. In Fig. 3a, a broad one at 1621 cm−1 for NH in‒plane bending appears at 250 °C and it distinctly increases in intensity at 300 °C. This band indicates the protonation of pyridine into pyridinium. At 200 °C, three new bands at 1552, 1479 and 1392 cm−1 become visible according to the metal surface selection rule. Analogously to pyridine adsorption on Ni [7], 1479 cm−1 relates to CC stretching of molecular pyridine on Pt, while the other two bands stem from CC or CN ring stretching of α-pyridyl species on Pt. The formation of α-pyridyl species induces the abstraction of H from α-C atom, which may contribute to the protonation of pyridine. The band at 1484 cm−1 gradually shifts to 1496 cm−1, and its intensity decreases at 200 °C then markedly increases at above 250 °C. Meanwhile, two new bands at 1365 and 1286 cm−1 for CH and NH bending vibrations of pyridinium on Pt appear above 250 °C. Overall, pyridine presents three patterns, i.e. pyridine molecule, pyridinium ion and α-pyridyl specie, on the surface of Pt/γ-Al2O3. This implies that Pt favors not only the dissociation of H2, but also the activation of pyridine. As shown in Fig. 4 , remarkable changes occur over Pt/γ-Al2O3 under H2 flow (case IV). When the temperature reaches 150 °C, the bands at 3100‒3000, 1218 and 1068 cm−1 relating to the vibration of pyridine on γ-Al2O3 vanish. 1479 cm−1 assigning to pyridine molecule on Pt also disappears. This is different from the former three cases (case I‒III), in which these bands remain visible even above 200 °C. At 250 °C, the newly formed band at 1552 cm−1 relating to α-pyridyl specie on Pt completely disappears, and the band at 1488 cm−1 shifts to 1498 cm−1 with a decreasing intensity. The change in these bands correlates to the continuous consumption of pyridine. On the other hand, some new bands appear when the temperature rises. At 150 °C, two discernible bands at 2948 and 2867 cm−1 appear in virtue of the symmetric and asymmetric CH2 stretching vibrations, respectively. The greater increase in the former band indicates this intermediate prefers a flat adsorption mode. Three weak bands at 1654, 1537 and 1187 cm−1 are owing to NH vibrations in different modes. We tentatively assign these new bands to the partially saturated pyridine. At 200 °C, two weak bands at 1332 and 1313 cm−1 for the wagging and twisting vibrations of CH2 groups become observable, indicating the formation of piperidine. As the temperature rises to 250 °C, the stretching vibrations of CH2 groups shift to 2956 and 2879 cm−1, respectively. This blue shift is caused by the overlapping bands of CH2 and CH3 stretching. Moreover, a weak signal appears at 1425 cm−1 due to CH2 scissoring. At 300 °C, the bands for CH2 and CH3 stretching further shift to 2958 and 2881 cm−1, respectively, indicating the proportion of CH3 group increases [44]. We tentatively speculate that the CH3 group belongs to the ring‒opening products. In order to investigate the evolution of pyridine hydrogenation, a time‒dependent experiment was conducted at a moderate temperature of 200 °C. As shown in Fig. 5 , the intensity and area of the bands at 2948 and 2867 cm−1 for CH2 groups increase with the elongated time, which indicates the enrichment of piperidine. Besides, two bands at 1654 and 1535 cm−1 associating with NH bending become stronger. The weak band at 1594 cm−1 gradually turns into an intense one at 1579 cm−1, indicating the evolution of aromatic CC bond to aliphatic CC bond. On the other hand, the intensity and area of the bands at 1625, 1548, 1498 and 1452 cm−1 all decrease due to the continuous consumption of pyridine species. In the low wavenumber region, the bands at 1332, 1313, 1274 and 1187 cm−1 relating to CH2 bending grow in intensity, while 1392, 1365 and 1286 cm−1 correspond to CH bending in pyridine decrease with elongated time. The evolution of these bands clearly states the hydrogenation of pyridine species to piperidine. 3.2 DFT calculations The HDN of pyridine basically undergoes successive hydrogenation and hydrogenolysis [45]. To get a better understanding of pyridine HDN over Pt surfaces, we have analyzed all elementary reaction steps on two major types of active sites: the terrace and step sites, which have been identified by CO FTIR measurements. 3.2.1 Adsorption of pyridine and derivatives Pyridine. Various geometries have been examined for pyridine adsorption on the terrace sites of Pt(111) and step sites of Pt(211) (Fig. S2 and S3). The most stable configurations are shown in Fig. 6 a‒b. Pyridine flatly adsorbs on Pt(111) and Pt(211) with a largest E ads of 1.32 and 1.37 eV, which is close to the results reported by Kolsbjerg et al. [12]. This reveals the preferential adsorption locates at the three-fold hollow sites with the pyridine ring parallel to rather than perpendicular to Pt surface. The result can be understood as that the π‒interaction is stronger than σ‒interaction due to larger overlap of the electron clouds. The stable configuration of pyridine adsorbed on Pt agrees with our FTIR observations, and similar to the results reported on MoP catalysts [27,28]. Since the aromatic pyridine ring is more readily activated via π‒interaction in the side‒on mode, Pt and phosphide catalysts may exhibit higher reactivity than the sulfide counterparts. Note that pyridine has slightly larger E ads on Pt(211) even without the bonding of N to Pt atoms. The interaction between pyridine and Pt slabs should mainly exist between C and Pt atoms. The bonding and charge transfer are clearly shown by the charge density difference (CDD) in Fig. 6c‒d. The distances of Pt‒C2 and Pt‒C5 are 2.25 and 2.23 Å on Pt(111), longer than those (2.24 and 2.21 Å) on Pt(211). In addition, the dehydrogenated α-pyridyl specie stably adsorbs on Pt(111) with a large E ads of −2.70 eV (Fig. S2), which have been confirmed by the IR band at 1552 cm−1 at above 250 °C under He flow. Intermediates. All possible intermediates have been examined in Tables S2−5. The adsorption geometries of the most favorable intermediates for pyridine hydrogenation on Pt(111) and Pt(211) are presented in Fig. 7 . The intermediates are named by the sequence of hydrogenated C atoms in the ring. The adsorption behaviors of the intermediates are similar to pyridine, except that the molecular plane becomes distorted by adding H atoms. 1-monohydropyridine (1-MHP) has an E ads of −2.24 eV on Pt(111), which increases to −3.06 eV on Pt(211). All of its C and N atoms nearly remain in the same plane. This is rational since H atom bonds to N atom via the lone pair electrons rather than the π‒electrons, the aromaticity of the ring is largely retained. The E ads increases to −2.68 eV for 1,3-dihydropyridine (13-DHP) on Pt(111) while decreases to −2.75 eV for 1,4-dihydropyridine (14-DHP) on Pt(211). Due to the steric hindrance of CH2 group, the C3 moves away from Pt(111) surface, while the ring of 14-DHP rotates on Pt(211). The E ads of 1,3,5-trihydropyridine (135-THP) on Pt(111) (−4.11 eV) turns to be higher than that of 1,4,3-trihydropyridine (143-THP) on Pt(211) (−3.30 eV). This superiority holds for 1,3,5,6-tetrahydropyridine (1356-TtHP) on Pt(111) with a higher E ads of −3.38 eV. The Pt‒C2 distance further increases to 2.20 and 2.13 Å on Pt(111) and Pt(211), respectively. E ads for 1,4,3,5,2-pentahydropyridine (14352-PHP) on Pt(211) (−2.43 eV) becomes higher than 1,3,5,6,2-pentahydropyridine (13562-PHP) on Pt(111) (−1.91 eV). For 14352-PHP, the C6 remains unsaturated and the Pt‒C6 distance is 2.16 Å. For 13562-PHP, both C2 and C6 are saturated with H atoms, leaving C4 bonds to Pt atom with a distance of 2.11 Å. Piperidine. Due to the weakened interaction between piperidine (Pip) and Pt surface, the E ads evidently lowers to 0.95 eV on Pt(111) and 0.98 eV on Pt(211). In line with FTIR results, the whole molecular plane of Pip uplifts away and flatly lies above the Pt surfaces, leaving two H atoms weakly bonding to two Pt atoms. The Pt‒H distances are equal to 1.94 Å on Pt(111), while 1.88 and 1.95 Å on Pt(211). 3.2.2 Hydrogenation of pyridine derivatives Pyridine conducts sequential hydrogenation over Pt surfaces according to the empirical Horiuti‒Polanyi mechanism [46]. H2 molecules spontaneously dissociate into H adatoms on Pt surfaces. Six H atoms are required to saturate the pyridine ring. As shown in Fig. 8 , the addition of the first H atom is thermodynamically and kinetically favorable on N atom to yield 1-MHP, regardless of the Pt facet. This step has an E a of 0.73 eV on Pt(111) with an exothermic E rxn of −0.40 eV, which further lowers to 0.62 eV on Pt(211) with a larger exothermic E rxn of −0.55 eV. The preferential formation of 1-MHP originates from the high proton affinity of N atom with lone pair electrons. The subsequent addition of five H atoms follows by different orders of C atoms: C3‒C5‒C6‒C2‒C4 on Pt(111) and C4‒C3‒C5‒C2‒C6 on Pt(211). In particular, the second H atom preferentially adds to C3 on Pt(111) and C4 on Pt(211). The corresponding E a is 1.17 and 0.37 eV, with an exothermic E rxn of -0.10 and -0.36 eV, respectively. When adding the third H to C5 on Pt(111), the E a lowers to -0.59 eV and the E rxn is almost thermoneutral (-0.04 eV). The formation of 143-THP on Pt(211) has a larger E a of 0.80 eV with a endothermic E rxn of 0.12 eV. After adding the fourth H atom, 1356-TtHP is the most favorable intermediate on Pt(111), with an endothermic E a (0.73 eV). While on Pt(211), 1435-TtHP is more likely to form. The E a is 0.85 eV with a thermoneutral E rxn of -0.01 eV. The addition of the fifth H to C2 has a lower E a on Pt(111) than Pt(211), with an approximately equal E rxn on two facets (0.23 vs. 0.24 eV). Adding the sixth H atom to yield Pip completely wipes out the π system. On Pt(111), this step needs to overcome a relatively large E a (1.20 eV). While on Pt(211), the E a lowers to 0.44 eV with an endothermic E rxn of 0.30 eV. The above results suggest that the hydrogenation of pyridine can readily take place on the Pt surfaces, which agrees with our FTIR results. Moreover, the energy barriers of pyridine hydrogenation on Pt are much lower than those on the sulfide and phosphide catalysts [27,28,47], which well explains the higher activity of Pt catalysts. 3.2.3 Hydrogenolysis of pyridine and derivatives Various possibilities have been considered for the ring opening of pyridine and its derivatives via hydrogenolysis. The configurations of transition states are displayed in Fig. 9 and Table 2 . The CN bond cleavage of pyridine needs to overcome a large E a either on Pt(111) or Pt(211). It is a strongly endothermic step with an E rxn of 2.20 and 1.50 eV, respectively. Thus, the direct CN bond cleavage of pyridine is impossible to occur on Pt surfaces. After hydrogenation, the E a for CN bond cleavage of 1-MHP sharply lowers either on Pt(111) or Pt(211), while an endothermic E rxn decreases to 0.53 and 1.20 eV, respectively. It is obvious that the CN bond cleavage of pyridine and 1-MHP have smaller E a on Pt(111) than those on Pt(211). However, the scenario is just vice versa once two H atoms have been added. The E a of CN bond cleavage becomes lower on Pt(211). CN cleavage of 13-DHP, 135-THP and 1356-TtHP on Pt(111) have larger E a of 2.00, 2.36 and 2.91 eV, while those of 14-DHP, 143-THP and 1435-TtHP on Pt(211) are 1.84, 2.35 and 2.46 eV, respectively. These steps are strongly endothermic that require high reaction temperature. Notably, the E a for CN bond cleavage of 14352-PHP on Pt(211) distinctly lowers to 0.17 eV with an endothermic E rxn of 0.68 eV, indicating this step takes place easily. The direct CN bond cleavage of 13562-PHP on Pt(111) has a large E a of 2.26 eV and an endothermic E rxn of 0.88 eV. Yet when CN cleavage occurs with assisted H attack, the E a decreases to 1.72 eV. After complete saturation, the E a for CN cleavage of Pip on Pt(111) markedly increases to 2.39 eV, while that on Pt(211) rebounds to 2.02 eV. Thus, we propose PHP, rather than Pip, is the real intermediate for CN bond cleavage during pyridine hydrodenitrogenation on Pt catalysts. Similar points have been made by previous studies [17,27] that TtHP was the real intermediate for the ring opening during pyridine HDN over the metal phosphide catalysts. 4 Discussion 4.1 The active sites for pyridine HDN over Pt/γ-Al2O3 catalysts CO FTIR and XPS measurements confirm that Pt mainly exists in the form of metallic Pt° on the surface of γ-Al2O3. Moreover, CO FTIR reveals that the active sites on Pt surface are composed of well-coordinated terrace sites and under-coordinated step sites. The in situ FTIR experiments show that pyridine remains unconverted over bare γ-Al2O3 under H2 flow. The inactivity of γ-Al2O3 can be interpreted from its poor ability to activate and dissociate H2 molecules, which is vital for the hydrogenation reaction. While on Pt/γ-Al2O3, several new bands assigned to pyridine adsorbing on Pt in three patterns, i.e. pyridine molecule, pyridinium ion and α-pyridyl specie, appear under He flow at above 150 °C. Thus, Pt can readily activate pyridine molecules, which leads to a lowered threshold for pyridine conversion. As expected, the hydrogenation reaction takes place prominently at 150 °C once the inlet gas is switched to H2. Evident signals for CH2 stretching appear at 2948 and 2867 cm−1. Moreover, weak vibrations of CH2 wagging and twisting appear at 200 °C. These bands are indicative of the formation of Pip. With further increasing temperature, the enhanced vibrations relating to CH3 stretching make the overlapped bands shift to 2958 and 2881 cm−1, which are probably attributed to the ring‒opening products. Hence, the in situ FTIR experiments signify that the active sites for pyridine HDN principally locate on Pt surface, which is consisted of terrace and step sites. The hydrogenation activity and selectivity of Pt catalysts are well known to be sensitive to the surface structures. According to the relationship between particle size and exposed site types proposed by Cai et al. [9], the surfaces of Pt nanoparticles (NPs) with a mean size of 2.9 nm on Pt/γ-Al2O3 catalyst used here are dominated by comparably large fractions of terrace sites (∼57 %) and step sites (∼38 %). Moreover, these two types of sites are routinely considered to be active sites for hydrogenation and hydrogenolysis reactions over the surface of transitional metal catalysts [38,48]. Based on these findings, the active sites for pyridine HDN are reasonably proposed to prevail at the flat terrace and stepped edge sites on Pt surface. The in situ FTIR experiments not only contribute to the identification of active sites, but also visually show the adsorption and stepwise reaction mechanism for pyridine HDN. This lays foundation for the DFT modeling and provides guidance for relating DFT calculations. 4.2 Difference between the terrace and step sites on Pt surface for pyridine HDN To better elucidate the mechanism of pyridine HDN over Pt surface, the reaction process has been comparatively studied over the terrace of Pt(111) and step of Pt(211) with DFT method. The optimized adsorption configuration of pyridine differs on these two types of sites, with η6(N,C2,C3,C4,C5,C6) on the terrace sites and η4(C2,C3,C4,C5) on the step sites. Despite that pyridine interacts with more surface Pt atoms at the terrace sites, the E ads is slightly lower than that at the step sites. To figure it out, we have calculated the d‒band center, a critical parameter determining the bonding capability of metal surface with adsorbate [49]. As previously reported by Watwe et al. [50], the PDOS analysis in Fig. 6e shows the terrace Pt atoms on Pt(111) has broader d‒band, and the d‒band center (-2.33 eV) locates 0.15 eV lower than that of the step Pt atoms on Pt(211). Since the valence electrons close to the Fermi level mainly govern the metal d states, the lower d‒electron density induces a weaker electronic interaction between surface terrace Pt atoms and pyridine. The bonding state and charge transfer are well illustrated by CDD maps in Fig. 6c-d. It is clear that remarkable charge redistributions occur with electrons transferring from surface Pt atoms to atop C atoms. The chemical bonding between these Pt and C atoms primarily devotes to the strength of pyridine adsorption. Additionally, three terrace Pt atoms (CN = 9) and two step Pt atoms (CN = 7) are involved, respectively, suggesting the under–coordinated step atoms contribute more to E ads. The sequential hydrogenation of pyridine follows different orders on the terrace and step sites, except that the reaction initiates both at N atom to form pyridinium. This protonation step occurs facilely with a low E a and an exothermic E rxn on these two sites, which is consistent with the FTIR results that NH bond substantially forms at 100 °C in H2. The subsequent hydrogenation steps take place symmetrically at endocyclic C atoms to form the metastable intermediates. By parallel comparison with the E a and E rxn of each elementary step, we find the hydrogenation process gets more energetic and thermodynamic driving force to proceed on the step sites. Moreover, the formation of Pip needs to overcome a large E a (1.20 eV) on Pt(111), whereas the dehydrogenation of 13562-PHP to 1356-TtHP has a low E a (0.22 eV) and exothermic E rxn (-0.23 eV). This reversible step may cause the accumulation of TtHP at moderate temperature, which matches with the IR band at 1479 cm−1 at 150 °C. As for hydrogenolysis, previous studies have long believed that the complete saturation of pyridine to Pip is a prerequisite [41,51]. This shall be unnecessary over Pt surfaces since the CN bond cleavage of PHP has much lower E a. In this case, all α- and β-carbon atoms of 13562-PHP are saturated with H atoms on Pt(111). Whereas one α-carbon atom of 14352-PHP remains unsaturated and accessible to Pt atom on Pt(211). Thus, different adsorption configurations of pyridine on the terrace and step sites result in different hydrogenated intermediates, which directly impacts the cleavage of CN bond. It remains controversial whether hydrogenation or hydrogenolysis is the rate determining step for HDN over sulfide catalysts [45,52]. While over Pt catalysts, the rate–determining step has been considered to be the hydrogenolysis of CN bond on Pt(111) and the hydrogenation of third H on Pt(211). The overwhelming superiority of the reactivity at the step sites derives from coordinatively unsaturated Pt atoms participating in bonding, which engineers a unique electronic band structure and facilitates the activation of hydrogenated intermediates. 4.3 Proposed reaction mechanism of pyridine HDN on Pt catalyst Numerous studies [25,45,52] have been undertaken to elucidate the reaction mechanism for HDN of nitrogen–containing heterocycles over conventional Mo(W)–based sulfide catalysts. To date, it is widely accepted that HDN of these compounds includes successive hydrogenation to saturate the heterocyclic ring, ring opening and deamination via hydrogenolysis of CN bond. Generally, the hydrogenation and hydrogenolysis are regarded to take place on different active sites [53], referring to (i) coordinatively unsaturated Mo centers (or sulfur vacancies) and brim sites, and (ii) neighboring –SH group (or Brønsted acid sites) at the edges, respectively. The carbocation mechanism indicates hydrogenation can be greatly enhanced by adding late 3d-transition metals (Ni, Co etc.) as promoters to form active sites with metallic character, whereas the mechanisms for hydrogenolysis is more complicated. Nucleophilic substitution and Hoffman β-H elimination, two well–known mechanisms firstly proposed by Nelson et al. [54], still work for the explanation of CN hydrogenolysis. The former involves a sp3-hybridized α-carbon atom, while the latter needs two sp3-hybridized α- and β-carbon atoms. Prins and Oyama et al. [55,56] proposed that CN hydrogenolysis predominantly occurred via a multistep NH2–SH substitution at the α-carbon atom. The incorporation of –SH group into primary amine resulting from nucleophilic attack by H2S led to the formation of alkanethiol, which later released H2S and NH3 to yield aliphatic hydrocarbons. The participation of metal centers has scarcely been concerned in CN hydrogenolysis. Laine [57] first proposed the mechanism for CN bond cleavage in saturated heterocyclic Pip over metal catalyst. They suggested a η2(N,C)-piperidyl complex produced via inserting a metal atom into α-C–H and NH bonds, and CN bond was cleaved via hydride attack at either α-carbon or N atom. With respect to pyridine HDN on Pt, the energy barriers for ring opening differ more than that for prior hydrogenation on Pt(111) and Pt(211) facets, which implies subsequent hydrogenolytic ring opening via CN bond is strongly structural– and/or size–dependent, and step Pt atoms have higher reactivity. Similar conclusions have been drawn for the hydrogenation of pyrrole over Pt catalysts [58]. Different intermediates generate when pyridine is hydrogenated on Pt(111) and Pt(211), which causes changes in the chemical environment of α-C–N bond. In terms of PHP, a crucial chemisorbed hydrogen–deficient intermediate, both α-C atoms are sterically hindered by H atoms on Pt(111), whereas an α-C atom directly bonds to Pt atom on Pt(211). The α-C atom activated by metallic Pt significantly weakens the CN bond, which plays a crucial role for the hydrogenolysis of nitrogen heterocycles. From this perspective, the CN bond cleavage of PHP occurs facilely on the step Pt atoms via a nucleophilic mechanism. Since the N atom in PHP does not bond to Pt atom on both facets, we speculate the nucleophilic attack susceptibly occurs at α-C atom rather than N atom. The relatively low E ads of Pip indicates Pip may desorb from Pt surfaces (especially Pt(111)) and be detected as a predominant product at relatively low temperature and pressure, as that experimentally confirmed [5]. We also find that CC bond cleavage is kinetically and thermodynamically unfavorable. Hence, the ring–opened n-pentylamine and five–carbon hydrocarbons will be the predominant products on Pt(211), and four–carbon hydrocarbons may become abundant at more stringent conditions, i.e. high temperature and pressure. Overall, the stepwise HDN differs from HDS reactions [32] over noble metals, which well interprets the difficulty in HDN. The viable reaction pathways for pyridine HDN on Pt surfaces are proposed in Fig. 10 . 5 Conclusions The reaction mechanism of pyridine HDN over Pt/γ-Al2O3 catalysts has been comprehensively elucidated via a combined experimental and theoretical study. The in situ CO FTIR experiments have identified that metallic Pt0 consisting of terrace and step Pt atoms dominantly serve as the active sites for pyridine HDN, which not only dissociate molecular H2 to active H species, but also activate pyridine to pyridinium ion and α-pyridyl species. DFT calculations indicate that pyridine most stably adsorbs on Pt surfaces in a parallel mode, and then undergoes stepwise hydrogenation and hydrogenolysis, which have been visually shown in the FTIR experiments. Prior hydrogenation significantly destroys the aromaticity of pyridine and facilitates subsequent hydrogenolysis. Notably, the H–deficient species, pentahydropyridine, rather than piperidine, is the real intermediate for CN bond cleavage, with an extremely low energy barrier of 0.17 eV on Pt(211). The analysis of surface electronic properties indicates that due to the presence of more coordinatively unsaturated step Pt atoms, Pt(211) outperforms Pt(111) in hydrogenation and shows overwhelming superiority in CN bond cleavage. Different hydrogenated intermediates form on these two facets, and it is obvious that the interaction between activated α-C and step Pt atoms majorly results in the weakened CN bond. Thus, the activity and selectivity should largely depend on the geometric structure of Pt nanoparticles, and the design of HDN catalysts with more step Pt atoms is highly desirable. Moreover, although γ-Al2O3 itself is inactive for HDN, the surface Lewis acid sites adjacent to metallic Pt may also contribute to CN bond cleavage. The ensemble of metallic and acid sites for hydrogenation and hydrogenolysis can be discussed in further study. coredata.dc:description: The hydrodenitrogenation of nitrogen-containing heterocycles over noble metals has fundamental importance for energy and environmental science. To develop more efficient catalyst, mechanistic investigation has been conducted with a method combining in situ Fourier transformation infrared experiments and density functional theory calculations in this work. The in situ experiments indicate flatly adsorbed pyridine molecules convert to pyridinium and α-pyridyl species at higher temperature on metallic Pt of Pt/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. Pyridine hydrogenation distinctly takes place at 150 °C with the appearance of methylene stretching vibrations, and a stepwise mechanism is identified as the temperature further increases. The adsorption, hydrogenation and hydrogenolysis of pyridine on Pt are studied in detail by theoretical calculations. In line with these findings, the geometry optimization confirms pyridine preferentially adsorbs on Pt(111) and Pt(211) both in a parallel configuration. Based on the Langmuir–Hinshelwood mechanism, the results show successive hydrogenation markedly lowers the energy barrier for subsequent hydrogenolysis. The CN bond cleavage occurs via nucleophilic attack of pentahydropyridine, rather than piperidine, which determines the reaction products, including piperidine, n-pentylamine and n-pentane. The comparative study reveals both hydrogenation and hydrogenolysis are kinetically and thermodynamically more competitive on Pt(211) than Pt(111). Especially for hydrogenolysis, the coordinatively unsaturated Pt step atoms play an essential role in CN bond cleavage. Thus, hydrogenolysis is more geometric‒dependent than hydrogenation. This provides instructive information for the design of catalysts with adjustable product selectivity.
coredata.dc:title: Molecular insights into the hydrodenitrogenation mechanism of pyridine over Pt/γ-Al2O3 catalysts

dcterms:subject.$: In situ Fourier transformation infrared spectroscopy
